title: HW3 Q4
content: Problem context: This problem builds on the problem from last week to gently expose you to core ideas related to reinforcement learning. The goal continues to be to both empower you and help you see your own empowerment: we didn't touch on this stuff at all during lecture or discussion. But you can still understand it. Whereas the earlier problem had you explore and understand via code and experimentation, this helps you look at a particular piece from a mathematical lens. The use of the standard normal is designed to help you see how helpful the normal distribution is when getting started vis-a-vis insight, while the later parts helps you see how the pattern extends beyond normals. (Although notice: the normal case is where it is easiest to discover what the pattern actually is.)
document:
Problem context: This problem builds on the problem from last week to gently expose you to core ideas related to reinforcement learning. The goal continues to be to both empower you and help you see your own empowerment: we didn't touch on this stuff at all during lecture or discussion. But you can still understand it. 

Whereas the earlier problem had you explore and understand via code and experimentation, this helps you look at a particular piece from a mathematical lens. The use of the standard normal is designed to help you see how helpful the normal distribution is when getting started vis-a-vis insight, while the later parts helps you see how the pattern extends beyond normals. (Although notice: the normal case is where it is easiest to discover what the pattern actually is.)

comments.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Is this the correct form?</paragraph><math>p_{\mu}(x)=(2\pi\sigma^2)^{-K/2}\exp\left(-\frac{|x-\mu|_2^2}{2\sigma^2}\right)</math><paragraph>Two small points I want to confirm:</paragraph><list style="ordered"><list-item><paragraph>n appears but isn’t defined—should we interpret (n = K) (the dimension of (x))?</paragraph></list-item><list-item><paragraph>Should the normalization constant use sigma^2<break/></paragraph><math>(i.e., ((2\pi\sigma^2)^{-K/2})) rather than ((2\pi\sigma)^{-n/2})?</math></list-item></list><paragraph>Thanks!</paragraph><paragraph/></document>
comments.document:
Is this the correct form?

$$p_{\mu}(x)=(2\pi\sigma^2)^{-K/2}\exp\left(-\frac{|x-\mu|_2^2}{2\sigma^2}\right)$$

Two small points I want to confirm:

n appears but isn’t defined—should we interpret (n = K) (the dimension of (x))?

Should the normalization constant use sigma^2


$$(i.e., ((2\pi\sigma^2)^{-K/2})) rather than ((2\pi\sigma)^{-n/2})?$$

Thanks!

comments.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Yes, n=k, we should unify that notation -- both are the dimensionality of x.</paragraph><paragraph>I believe you are right for the bottom question as well -- we are considering a standard multivariate Gaussian so the normalization constant should include the variance, i.e. sigma^2.</paragraph></document>
comments.document:
Yes, n=k, we should unify that notation -- both are the dimensionality of x.

I believe you are right for the bottom question as well -- we are considering a standard multivariate Gaussian so the normalization constant should include the variance, i.e. sigma^2.

comments.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>For part (e), shouldn't the RHS be the expectation where z is drawn from pz (that probability distribution) and not curly Z (the set). How can you sample from a set.</paragraph></document>
comments.document: For part (e), shouldn't the RHS be the expectation where z is drawn from pz (that probability distribution) and not curly Z (the set). How can you sample from a set.

comments.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Yes, that should be z drawn from p(z).</paragraph></document>
comments.document: Yes, that should be z drawn from p(z).

comments.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Can I understand this question as when the loss function can be written as an expectation, according to the meaning of this question, its gradient is also in the expected form, so SGD is similar to Monte Carlo simulation, and it'll perform well?</paragraph></document>
comments.document: Can I understand this question as when the loss function can be written as an expectation, according to the meaning of this question, its gradient is also in the expected form, so SGD is similar to Monte Carlo simulation, and it'll perform well?

comments.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>I think you're right. The problem is basically showing that if we can rewrite the gradient as an expectation (like in the reparameterization trick), we can just sample from that distribution to estimate it. I think that's why the homework concludes that these tricks are useful.</paragraph></document>
comments.document: I think you're right. The problem is basically showing that if we can rewrite the gradient as an expectation (like in the reparameterization trick), we can just sample from that distribution to estimate it. I think that's why the homework concludes that these tricks are useful.
